statement: If two angles form a linear pair, then they are supplementary.
If two lines are cut by a transversal and corresponding angles are congruent, then the lines are parallel.
If two angles are vertical angles, then they are congruent.
If a transversal intersects two parallel lines, then alternate interior angles are congruent.
If two triangles have three pairs of congruent sides, then the triangles are congruent. (SSS)
If two triangles have two pairs of congruent sides and the included angle is congruent, then the triangles are congruent. (SAS)
If two triangles have two angles and the included side congruent, then the triangles are congruent. (ASA)
In a triangle, the sum of the interior angles is 180 degrees.
Base angles of an isosceles triangle are congruent.
The diagonals of a rectangle are congruent.
The diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular.
The opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.
If a radius is perpendicular to a chord, then it bisects the chord.
The measure of an inscribed angle is half the measure of its intercepted arc.
If two segments are both perpendicular to the same line, then they are parallel to each other.
If two triangles have all corresponding angles congruent, then the triangles are similar. (AAA Similarity)
If two triangles have two pairs of sides in proportion and the included angles congruent, then the triangles are similar. (SAS Similarity)
If two triangles have three pairs of sides in proportion, then the triangles are similar. (SSS Similarity)
If a line parallel to one side of a triangle intersects the other two sides, it divides them proportionally.
The Pythagorean Theorem states that in a right triangle, a² + b² = c².
In coordinate geometry, the distance between two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is √[(x₂−x₁)² + (y₂−y₁)²].
The midpoint between two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) is ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2).
The slope of the line through two points is (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁), if x₁ ≠ x₂.
The area of a triangle is (1/2) × base × height.
The area of a circle is πr² and the circumference is 2πr.
In a circle, congruent chords are equidistant from the center.
The perpendicular bisector of a chord passes through the center of the circle.
In a triangle, the angle opposite the longer side is larger.
The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle is greater than the length of the third side.
If two segments are both perpendicular to the same segment and lie on the same plane, then they are parallel.
Corresponding Parts of Congruent Triangles are Congruent (CPCTC).
If two angles are supplements of the same angle, then they are congruent.
If two segments (or angles) are both congruent to a third one, they are congruent to each other (transitive property).
Vertical angles are always congruent.
If two lines are cut by a transversal and corresponding angles are congruent, the lines are parallel.
A reflection over a line produces a mirror image with equal distance from the line of reflection.
A rotation of a figure about a point preserves distances and angle measures.
A dilation centered at a point with scale factor k multiplies all distances from the center by k.
Translations shift all points of a figure the same distance in the same direction.
Rigid motions preserve angle measures and side lengths; thus, they preserve congruence.
The volume of a rectangular prism is length × width × height.
The volume of a cylinder is πr²h.
The volume of a cone is (1/3)πr²h.
The volume of a sphere is (4/3)πr³.
The surface area of a sphere is 4πr².
The centroid of a triangle with vertices (x₁, y₁), (x₂, y₂), and (x₃, y₃) is at ((x₁+x₂+x₃)/3, (y₁+y₂+y₃)/3).
The equation of the perpendicular bisector of a segment can be found using the negative reciprocal of the slope and the midpoint.
The general form of a circle centered at (h, k) with radius r is (x−h)² + (y−k)² = r².
A line is tangent to a circle if it intersects the circle at exactly one point and is perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact.
The length of a tangent segment from a point outside a circle to the point of tangency is equal on both sides.
If two chords intersect inside a circle, then the products of the segments of each chord are equal.
If a secant and a tangent intersect outside a circle, then the product of the secant's entire length and its external part equals the square of the tangent segment.
If two secants intersect outside a circle, then the product of one secant's entire length and its external part equals that of the other.
The composition of two reflections over intersecting lines results in a rotation.
The composition of two reflections over parallel lines results in a translation.
An indirect proof assumes the opposite of the desired conclusion and derives a contradiction.
To prove a biconditional statement, both the conditional and its converse must be proven true.
In a circle, the product of the lengths of the segments of intersecting chords is invariant.
In an isosceles triangle, the angle bisector from the vertex angle is also the median to the base.
In a triangle, the angle bisector of an angle divides the opposite side in the ratio of the adjacent sides.
A non-degenerate segment length is always positive real number. If you get algebraic solution, make sure you plug it back into geometric object to figure out whether the value is valid.
